news.author: Sophie Perry

news.title: Does JD Vance have a Palantir problem? Growing scrutiny
news.text:
What began as a routine Democratic talking point ‚Äî focused on Vance‚Äôs ties to Palantir co-founder Peter Thiel, who mentored Vance early in his career and poured $15 million into his 2022 Senate run ‚Äî has now become a source of tension within Trump‚Äôs own political coalition, News.Az reports, citing foreign media.
In recent weeks, several prominent conservative figures, including Steve Bannon, Joe Rogan, and Roger Stone, have expressed unease about Palantir‚Äôs growing footprint in federal agencies. Stone even said he warned Vance directly that his ‚Äúbiggest fear for the country is Palantir,‚Äù citing concerns about futuristic, large-scale government surveillance.
Vance has dismissed these claims, telling young conservatives that accusations he is ‚Äúin bed‚Äù with the company are nothing more than an ‚Äúinternet meme.‚Äù He insists Palantir is simply a private contractor that provides both helpful and controversial services.
Despite attempts to distance himself, Palantir has become deeply embedded in the federal government:
Department of Veterans Affairs
State Department
Pentagon and U.S. Army
The company has secured billions in federal deals since Trump took office, including a potential $10 billion Army contract, while its stock price has tripled since the election.
Its software is now central to major policy areas, such as immigration enforcement and federal workforce restructuring, both top priorities for Trump‚Äôs second term.
Concerns escalated after a March executive order mandated broader interagency data coordination. Critics across the political spectrum fear that combining Palantir‚Äôs tools with advanced AI could give the government unprecedented insight into Americans‚Äô private lives.
Palantir strongly denies those claims, saying in a June statement:
‚ÄúWe are not a surveillance company‚Ä¶ We do not sell personal data‚Ä¶ We don‚Äôt provide data-mining as a service.‚Äù
Still, as the company's influence grows, skepticism only intensifies.
Vance has attempted to strike a middle ground. He argues that Big Tech platforms collecting consumer data for profit pose a bigger privacy threat than Palantir‚Äôs government contracts. Yet he also acknowledges that modern technology is ‚Äúcrazy and weird,‚Äù with real implications for civil liberties.
His position is delicate. Trump has increasingly surrounded himself with Silicon Valley billionaires, even as the GOP‚Äôs populist wing becomes more suspicious of tech giants. Recent flashpoints include:
Bannon‚Äôs ongoing clashes with Elon Musk
Ron DeSantis sounding alarms about energy-hungry data centers
Josh Hawley pushing investigations into AI-related harms
Against this backdrop, Vance ‚Äî once a venture capitalist and long-time Thiel prot√©g√© ‚Äî stands between two worlds: conservative populists and tech elites.
Palantir CEO Alex Karp, who backed Kamala Harris in 2024 before shifting toward Trump post-election, has built close ties with the new administration and donated to pro-Trump groups. Former Palantir adviser Jacob Helberg now holds a senior State Department role.
Their growing visibility has angered activists like Laura Loomer, who accuses Palantir of trying to ‚Äúinfiltrate‚Äù the administration to secure massive defense contracts.
For now, Vance has not proposed any specific steps to address privacy or data protection concerns. None of Trump‚Äôs 213 executive orders to date prioritize consumer data safeguards, and the administration recently backed moves to block state-level AI regulations.
As Palantir cements its position in Washington and skepticism grows among the MAGA base, Vance must navigate conflicting pressures:
loyalty to Trump‚Äôs governing agenda
distrust from conservative activists
his own deep ties to the tech sector
How he manages this divide may shape both Trump‚Äôs coalition ‚Äî and Vance‚Äôs long-term political trajectory.

news.title: Experts say recent elections in blue areas bode well for Democrats but Trump coalition holding firm
news.text:
MADISON - Do Democratic sweeps in blue areas of the country mean anything for the next election battle in purple Wisconsin?

Political experts say the voter enthusiasm on display in races earlier this month in New Jersey, Virginia and elsewhere could mean Democrats have tailwinds heading into the midterms in the Badger State, which is much more divided politically.

It's one of the first data points political observers are using to make predictions about the upcoming midterm elections, which will take place two years into President Donald Trump's second term and will feature the first wide-open Wisconsin governor's race in more than a decade.

"It's another sign Democrats have the edge in general going into 2026," Barry Burden, a University of Wisconsin-Madison political science professor and director of the university's Elections Research Center, said about the election outcomes.

Both Democratic candidates for governor in New Jersey and Virginia ran ahead of former Vice President Kamala Harris' electoral result in 2024. In legislative races in Virginia, Democrats flipped 13 seats in the House.

"Those swings from year to year do say something about change despite the fact that they were Democratic-leaning states. And I think that is really relevant," Charles Franklin, Marquette University Law School poll director, said.

Franklin said the Republicans who lost Nov. 4 won by an average of 5¬Ω points two years ago. This time, they lost by an average of six points.

"That's an 11¬Ω-point swing in the margins in those Republican incumbent seats over just a two-year period," Franklin said.

The swing is likely tied to voter opinions about the job Trump is doing since his inauguration in January and cost-of-living worries.

"The economy could change in 12 months. I'm not making any economic forecasts, but I am saying, you'll want to keep an eye on whether the public remains as concerned about economic issues over the next 12 months," Franklin said.

"And if so, the results this week show what a challenge that can be for the incumbent party."

But Franklin also said Trump's approval in Wisconsin has not waned as much as it has nationally and certainly less than in the more Democratic-leaning areas, giving Republicans an advantage they may not have elsewhere.

"That's maybe a glimpse of good news for Republicans here that the president doesn't seem as unpopular in Wisconsin as he does in other states," Franklin said. "His coalition isn't visibly cracking up here in Wisconsin. It's holding quite firm."

Republicans discount results from blue states New Jersey and Virginia

Republican Party of Wisconsin spokeswoman Anika Rickard said the New Jersey and Virginia races didn't hold any predictions for upcoming races in Wisconsin in her view.

"Those are very blue states. They've been blue for a while. In the last 13 off-year elections in Virginia, in only one has the party that controls the White House won the governor's race. So it's not unexpected to see the results there and in New Jersey," Rickard said.

"I don't think it says a lot about whether or not there will be a blue wave next year. I think Democrats are really gripping onto that, to energize their base, but I don't see that coming to fruition in Wisconsin."

Devin Remiker, chairman of the Democratic Party of Wisconsin, disagreed, saying potential voters are telling party volunteers they aren't happy with household prices ‚Äî an issue he identified as driving the results of the elections earlier this month.

"In the races across the country, there was a resounding rejection of Donald Trump and the Republican Party. And something that wasn't surprising to me was that voters are rejecting Republican candidates largely because they have disappointed them on the most critical issue, which is the cost of living and inflation," Remiker said.

Just days after the Democratic victories, Democrats relented on a strategy to push Republicans to include an extension of Obamacare subsidies in a new bill to fund the federal government.

More: 7 in 10 want ACA subsidies to continue, Marquette poll says

A recent national Marquette University Law School poll showed voters across the political spectrum disapproved of the way Trump handled the federal government shutdown, which lasted more than 40 days.

Democrats forced the shutdown by demanding that any new spending bill include the subsidies. But at the end, a group of Democrats agreed to vote with Republicans to pass a bill without that provision.

Remiker said he thinks those Democrats gave up momentum.

"I think the victory that we got out of this process was clearly connecting Republicans to what they have done, which is to further deny people the ability to put food on the table and to leave health care an unanswered question," he said.

"One of the most stark results after election night was how some Republicans were shifting their vote a little bit. It felt like we had momentum on this issue. And I think it was a little too soon to give up that fight."

Still, Remiker said new votes on the health care issue will play a key role in Democrats' strategy for the midterms.

Meanwhile, Rickard said Republicans are on better footing for the midterms given voters' low view of Democrats.

"Trump's approval ratings go up and down. They always have. But one thing that we've seen is the Democrat Party's approval rating continues to sit very low, lower than Republicans," she said. "I think that's more of a devastating sign to them than an up and down polling for us and President Trump. We can always get those polling numbers back up, but Democrats haven't seemed to be able to figure out how to get their polling numbers up."

Democrats could gain from motivated voters

Franklin said the flip side of Trump's approval in Wisconsin, which is higher than the national average, is that Democratic enthusiasm for voting is high and voters continue to be unhappy with the cost of living.

"When we get to the turnout game of who turns out in a midterm, highly, highly motivated Democrats may expand their turnout advantage a little bit beyond what we've seen in previous years," he said.

Nearly every statewide office will feature an open race with no incumbent in 2026, with the exception of the offices of attorney general and treasurer.

In the governor's race, the most high-profile contest in 2026, seven major candidates are running campaigns. In the coming days, former Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes is expected to join the Democratic primary.

More: Gilbert: With no incumbent and no big names, the 2026 Wisconsin governor's race is shaping up as unusual

Also in focus is how the state Legislature might change after the 2026 elections. Under new electoral maps, Democrats have a better chance than in cycles past to pick up more seats.

"It's easy to imagine Democrats even in a neutral environment picking up a seat or two. If they have some tailwinds because of the national tide pushing in their favor, it's possible they could flip the state Senate," Burden said. "Even if they don't win the governor's race, I would say. There's still a possibility of a kind of split outcome there."

Molly Beck can be reached at molly.beck@jrn.com.
news.author: Journal Sentinel

news.title: Charlie Kirk's wife reveals she was 'praying to God' she was pregnant when her husband was killed
news.text:
Erika Kirk, the widow of conservative activist Charlie Kirk, said she had been 'praying to God' she was pregnant when her husband was shot and killed in September.

Erika was speaking with Megyn Kelly during a live on-stage interview in Arizona on Friday when she revealed how her longing for a larger family sparked the revelation. 

'I was praying to God that I was pregnant when he got murdered,' Erika told Kelly during a tour stop in Glendale.

'You told me this in private - How many kids did you want to have?' Megyn asked.

'We wanted to have four,' Erika responded.

'Oh, wow,' Megyn replied. 'I thought of that once. Whether it was meant to be or whether we'd get news like that.'

Erika continued: 'I was like, oh, goodness, that was going to be the ultimate blessing out of this catastrophe.'

Charlie Kirk, founder of Turning Point USA and one of the most visible conservative activists in the country, was shot and killed in September while speaking to students at Utah Valley University in Orem. 

She then urged young women not to wait to start having children. 

'When I see young couples, I tell them, "Please, don't put it off." Especially if you're a young woman. Don't put it off, you can always have a career, you can always, you know, go back to work. You can never just go back to having children. And they grow so fast and so quickly,' she urged.

'I was praying. Both of us were. We were just excited to just expand our family.' 

Kelly told her, 'Thank God you have the two. Thank God.'

'A boy and girl. I know,' Erika said, adding that one day they will understand their father's public role. 

Kelly said, 'One day they'll find out they're Charlie Kirk's children and they'll know what that means,' drawing applause from the crowd.

Friday‚Äôs interview marked one of Erika Kirk‚Äôs most personal public comments since her husband‚Äôs assassination.

Police arrested 22-year-old Tyler Robinson for Charlie Kirk's murder. Authorities say he turned himself in shortly after the shooting.

The killing prompted swift reactions across the conservative movement. 

Kirk's memorial service, held at State Farm Stadium in Arizona, drew President Donald Trump, Vice President JD Vance, and a wide range of Republican officials and influencers.

At the service Kirk‚Äôs widow Erika took to the stage at his memorial service to deliver powerful remarks on his life and legacy, even astonishingly forgiving his alleged assassin Tyler Robinson in her moving speech.

Charlie Kirk 'wanted to save young men just like the one who took his life,' Erika said at her husband's memorial. 'I forgive him,' she said as the crowd erupted in applause.

'I forgive him because it's what Christ did. The answer to hate is not hate.'

Kirk founded Turning Point USA in 2012 and built it into the most prominent conservative youth organization in the country. 

Trump praised him as one of the 'key reasons' he won reelection.

But Kirk's prominence also brought criticism. 

He attacked gay and transgender rights, frequently engaged in high-profile cultural disputes, and amplified Trump's false claims that former Vice President Kamala Harris encouraged migrants to enter the US illegally. 

He also drew condemnation for calling George Floyd a 'scumbag,' remarks that fueled accusations he inflamed racial tensions for political gain.
news.summary: Erika Kirk opened up to Megyn Kelly about a private hope she carried in the moments after her husband's killing. The revelation stunned Kelly when she repeated it onstage.
news.author: Editor,James Gordon

news.title: Why Gen Z Right Finds A New MAGA Champion In Nikki Haley's Son Nalin Haley
news.text: Nalin Haley, the 24-year-old son of former South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley, is now one of the most popular young voices on the American right.After a high-visibility appearance on Tucker Carlson's show and a rapid surge in online following, political commentators are beginning to see him as a potential new face of a shifting MAGA movement.The last thing an H-1B visa worker sees before getting sent backThank you to @TuckerCarlson for having me. Interview starts at 46:45. We talk about:* My conversion to Catholicism* The mainstream media* Economy* Immigration* Foreign Policy https://t.co/G7zEJFY9hW pic.twitter.com/bEMuTVCl7T‚Äî Nalin Haley (@Nalin_Haley) November 20, 2025A widely shared X post by right-wing commentator Evan Kilgore read, ‚ÄúNalin Haley is going to quickly rise to become the face of the male Gen Z Right-Wing.‚Äù‚ÄúThe kid is going places,‚Äù he added.I'm calling it right now.Nalin Haley is going to quickly rise to become the face of the male Gen Z Right-Wing.I've watched multiple interviews with him. He is extremely well spoken and has based views on immigration and foreign policy.This kid is going places. @Nalin_Haley https://t.co/GVUaqwdJQE pic.twitter.com/mpEZy4vqFi‚Äî Evan Kilgore ???????? (@EvanAKilgore) November 20, 2025Nalin Haley's rise coincides with young Americans' growing demand for the way Republicans approach politics, something he shed light on during his conversation with Carlson.Exit polls from the 2024 election showed Donald Trump leading Vice President Kamala Harris by 14 points among male Gen Z voters. While older Gen Z Americans remain more mixed politically, younger Gen Z men and younger Gen Z women appear increasingly inclined toward Republican positions, according to the Yale Youth Poll.Haley's commentary on nationalism, anti-establishment anger, and cultural grievance has made him appealing to this younger conservative base. After being labelled everything from ‚ÄúFascist‚Äù to ‚ÄúWoke Right‚Äù, he wrote on X, ‚ÄúYou're not radical for wanting [these things]. You're rational.‚ÄùYou're not radical for wanting a job, affordable housing, and safe streets. You're rational! Don't let anyone convince you otherwise‚Äî Nalin Haley (@Nalin_Haley) November 9, 2025During his recent interview with Tucker Carlson, Haley outlined a series of hardline proposals. He argued that naturalised citizens should not be allowed to hold public office, saying that being raised in the US from birth is ‚Äúa big part of understanding the country.‚Äù The position has implications for current officeholders, including Democratic New York Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani, who is naturalised.Haley also called for limiting foreign students in US universities, saying, ‚ÄúSome of them are spies, by the way.‚Äù He called for banning dual citizenship, which he described as ‚Äúthe stupidest idea.‚Äù He also spoke about disallowing foreign military service, calling it inherently disqualifying for anyone with ties to the US.‚ÄúYou are either American, or you're not an American,‚Äù Haley said.Days before that, he argued for halting ‚Äúlegal immigration,‚Äù linking it to job scarcity for young Americans. In an interview with UnHerd, he said none of his high-achieving friends could find work a year and a half after graduating.‚ÄúSo when you see a bunch of foreigners coming over here to take jobs that [my friends] wanted,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúthey have every right to be pissed, and I'm pissed for them.‚ÄùPolitical experts say Haley's appeal is a slow migration away from Trump's original 2016 vision. Thomas Gift, director of the Centre on US Politics at University College London, told Newsweek, ‚ÄúTrump has unleashed a political creature with MAGA one he can no longer fully control‚Ä¶ In many ways, Trump is now too tame for parts of the movement he started. That may include rising leaders like Nalin Haley.‚ÄùAdam Hilton, a politics professor at Mount Holyoke College, said Haley shows a growing trend within the far-right space during Trump's second administration. ‚ÄúThe race is on to succeed Trump as the leader of the MAGA movement,‚Äù Hilton said, noting a ‚Äúdeep bench‚Äù of ambitious contenders.Haley has repeatedly rejected political labels, insisting he does not feel represented by either party. ‚ÄúI don't feel represented by anybody,‚Äù he told Carlson.
news.summary: Nalin Haley, the 24-year-old son of former South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley, is now one of the most popular young voices on the American right.

news.title: Donald Trump, 79, Demands Reboot of Retired Movie Franchise
news.text:
Home Alone 2: Lost in New York star Donald Trump is reportedly leaning on one of his billionaire buddies to get his Hollywood studio to resurrect one of his movie favorites.

Trump, 79, is close to Paramount‚Äôs owner Larry Ellison, the world‚Äôs third-richest man, who has also donated heavily to the president‚Äôs campaigns.

Ellison‚Äôs studio Paramount, which is run by his son David, is set to take over the Warner movie catalogue and production company. A new report in Semafor claims that Trump is already making suggestions about future Paramount projects‚Äîand one franchise in particular. 

The publication cites someone directly familiar with the conversations saying that Trump ‚Äúpersonally pressed‚Äù Ellison to revive the Jackie Chan/Chris Tucker buddy-cop franchise Rush Hour.

The first Rush Hour was released in 1998 and grossed $245.3 million worldwide. It was followed by Rush Hour 2 in 2001 and Rush Hour 3 in 2007.

The Daily Beast has contacted the White House and Paramount for comment.

Warner severed their relationship with Rush Hour director Brett Ratner in 2017 after allegations of sexual misconduct, including from Juno star Elliot Page. He has denied the claims. Ratner previously had a production deal with the company worth $450 million.

Semafor suggests that while other studios potentially did not want to touch a Rush Hour reboot if Ratner was involved, it may not be an issue for Paramount as the director of Trump‚Äôs beloved franchise has strong MAGA links.

Ratner‚Äôs first project since the misconduct claims is a $40 million documentary on Melania Trump due to be released in January through Amazon. 

It follows the first lady for the 20 days before the 2025 inauguration of her husband, which was attended by a line-up to tech titans including. Amazon founder Jeff Bezos.

Arthur Sarkissian, who produced the Rush Hour franchise, steered the production company behind last year‚Äôs The Man You Don‚Äôt Know, a fawning Trump documentary which has a 4 out of 10 rating on movie site IMDB.

Jackie Chan, who is now 71, was diplomatic when asked about Trump‚Äôs looming presidency in 2016, saying, ‚ÄúJust give him a chance to try to change America and change the world. He‚Äôs a businessman‚Ä¶ I think he knows how to handle these types of things.‚Äù

Whether Trump greenlights the casting of Tucker‚Äôs return is less clear. Tucker is friendly with Democratic former presidents Bill Clinton and Barack Obama and in July 2024 was pictured holding a Kamala Harris sign while attending a campaign rally for the Democratic presidential candidate in Georgia. 

Trump is also fond of the 1988 Jean-Claude Van Damme movie Bloodsport, telling The New Yorker the action film was ‚Äúan incredible, fantastic movie.‚Äù

The president‚Äôs other favorite movies include Goodfellas, Gone With the Wind, Citizen Kane, The Godfather, and The Good, The Bad and the Ugly.
news.summary:
M. Tran / FilmMagicHome Alone 2: Lost in New York star Donald Trump is reportedly leaning on one of his billionaire buddies to get his Hollywood studio to resurrect one of his movie favorites.

Trump, 79, is close to Paramount‚Äôs owner Larry Ellison, the world‚Äôs third-richest man, who has also donated heavily to the president‚Äôs campaigns.

As well as owning a large stake in software giant Oracle, Ellison has been named as one of the Trump allies who could potentially take over ownership of TikTok.

Read more at The Daily Beast.
news.author: Cameron Adams

news.title: Does JD Vance have a Palantir problem?
news.text: In a recent conversation, Vice President JD Vance asked Roger Stone, President Donald Trump‚Äôs longtime confidant, for his biggest concern facing the country. Stone later recalled on his radio show that his answer was a technology company Vance now hears about with increasing frequency: Palantir. For years, Democrats have zeroed in on Vance‚Äôs relationship with Palantir‚Äôs co-founder Peter Thiel, the iconoclastic tech titan who gave Vance one of his first jobs and later put $15 million behind his successful 2022 Ohio Senate bid. But the pressure on Vance is now coming from inside Trump‚Äôs coalition. As the administration steers billions of dollars of new work to Palantir, prominent voices have expressed fears that the firm‚Äôs powerful data analytics tools could give the government sweeping, almost futuristic surveillance capabilities. MAGA architect Steve Bannon has likened Palantir to a sci-fi villain while comedian Joe Rogan called the company ‚Äúcreepy‚Äù on his top-ranked podcast. The rising unease has put Vance on the defensive. At an October gathering of young conservatives at the University of Mississippi, he bristled at ‚Äúthis internet meme out there that somehow I am super in bed with Palantir‚Äù when the company‚Äôs name surfaced. ‚ÄúPalantir is a private company,‚Äù Vance added. ‚ÄúThey sometimes do a useful service, and sometimes they‚Äôre going to do things that we don‚Äôt like.‚Äù Since rising to the national scene, Vance has served as a bridge between the GOP‚Äôs populist wing and the tech world he once occupied as a venture capitalist and biotech executive. He joined the Republican ticket last year with the backing of Bannon and former Fox News host Tucker Carlson, but also with the expectation he could convince his Silicon Valley allies to open their wallets for the campaign. Palantir‚Äôs emergence as an unlikely flashpoint comes amid a growing divide within the party over Trump‚Äôs alliance with billionaire technology entrepreneurs. The tensions underscore the challenge ahead for Vance as he takes a leading role in helping to hold together Trump‚Äôs movement ‚Äî a task with clear implications for his own political ambitions. Vance‚Äôs office did not respond to a request for comment. A spokesperson for Palantir pointed CNN to a lengthy statement the company published in June, which seeks to rebut what it describes as ‚Äúrecurrent misconceptions‚Äù about its operations. ‚ÄúWe are not a surveillance company,‚Äù the statement reads. ‚ÄúWe do not sell personal data of any kind. We don‚Äôt provide data-mining as a service.‚Äù A contracting behemoth Founded two decades ago with a funding boost from American intelligence agencies, Palantir has become a go-to contractor for governments and businesses confronting enormous and complex data problems. Federal agencies, local police departments and foreign militaries increasingly rely on its software and AI models, but so do aerospace companies, hospitals and the makers of a pickleball paddle. Palantir‚Äôs government portfolio grew during Trump‚Äôs first term and expanded further under President Joe Biden. CEO Alex Karp backed Democrat Kamala Harris for president, but like many of his tech peers, he quickly pivoted after Trump won. A month after the election, Karp contributed $1 million to the leading pro-Trump super PAC. Around the same time, Palantir ads appeared over Trump and Vance‚Äôs box at the Army-Navy football game, and the company is among the donors to Trump‚Äôs new White House ballroom. Jacob Helberg, a former adviser to Karp, is now a top official in the State Department. Skeptical MAGA activists noticed. Far-right influencer Laura Loomer accused the firm last year of trying to ‚Äúinfiltrate‚Äù the incoming administration to secure defense contracts. Nearly every week, another US agency assigns lucrative new work to Palantir. In recent months, the company has been hired by the Department of Homeland Security to vet ‚Äúwedding-based schemes,‚Äù by the Department of Veteran Affairs to track statistics, by the Internal Revenue Service to help cut costs and by the State Department to identify threats to Americans and US diplomats overseas, according to federal contracting data. Palantir‚Äôs tools have supported some of Trump‚Äôs most contentious priorities, including DOGE‚Äôs push to downsize government and the administration‚Äôs immigration crackdown. The dozens of contracts awarded to Palantir since Trump took office can be measured in billions of dollars ‚Äî including a decade-long deal with the US Army worth up to $10 billion. Palantir‚Äôs stock price has nearly tripled since Trump was elected. But the expanding footprint inside the government has fueled fears that Palantir‚Äôs advanced tools ‚Äî coupled with cutting edge breakthroughs, like artificial intelligence, facial recognition software and predictive algorithms ‚Äî could lead to high-tech mass surveillance. A key source of concern for critics on both the right and left is an executive order Trump signed in March commanding agencies to share data with each other, though it doesn‚Äôt mention surveillance or Palantir. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like the stated plans of Palantir,‚Äù Stone told Vance, he later recalled to his listeners. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want Big Brother knowing everything about me.‚Äù Palantir has pushed back aggressively against the emerging narrative surrounding its government work. In a recent media blitz, Karp has defensively described Palantir as patriotic. He told Fortune magazine its software is a tool ‚Äúto make America so strong we never fight.‚Äù He has also insisted Palantir programs can‚Äôt be used to abuse civil rights, while also dismissing fears about governments tracking their citizens. ‚ÄúThe primary evidence for a surveillance state in the West is not government on consumer; it‚Äôs a company knowing every single action you have at all times,‚Äù he said in an interview with Axios‚Äô Mike Allen. But that hasn‚Äôt stopped concerns from reaching Vance. On his show ‚ÄúThis Past Weekend,‚Äù comedian Theo Von pressed Vance this summer on Palantir and Thiel‚Äôs influence, calling the company‚Äôs capabilities ‚Äúreally scary.‚Äù Vance downplayed Palantir‚Äôs role as ‚Äújust connecting information‚Äù between agencies. Like Karp, he contended the relentless collection of data on Americans by private companies in the name of commerce is a greater threat than Palantir‚Äôs government work, while also acknowledging that modern technology is ‚Äúcrazy and weird and it affects our privacy.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe only real protection that we have against that is that we‚Äôve got to elect the right people,‚Äù Vance said. Von, a key voice in helping Trump connect with young men last year, later called Vance‚Äôs response a ‚Äúpolitical answer.‚Äù MAGA tensions over Big Tech Vance has long tried to square his professed skepticism of Big Tech with his deep ties to some of the industry‚Äôs most influential figures. He once wrote that hearing Thiel speak at Yale was the ‚Äúmost significant moment‚Äù of his law school years and later joined Thiel‚Äôs venture capital firm. When Vance started his own fund in 2020, Thiel joined former Google CEO Eric Schmidt and billionaire investor Marc Andreessen as backers. But during his Ohio Senate campaign, despite Thiel‚Äôs generous financial backing, Vance routinely attacked Facebook ‚Äî where Thiel was an early investor and longtime board member ‚Äî as well as Google. Probed about Palantir at the Ole Miss event, Vance acknowledged concerns about artificial intelligence facilitating ‚Äúlarge-scale surveillance.‚Äù He argued he has fought against intrusive data collection practices since he first ran for Senate. ‚ÄúWhether it‚Äôs Palantir or any other technology company,‚Äù he said. (Palantir insists it doesn‚Äôt collect or sell data on individuals.) A Vance spokesperson did not respond to questions about how he has pushed the administration on privacy issues. None of the 213 executive orders Trump has signed since taking office have emphasized data protections for consumers, and this week, Trump publicly threw his support for blocking state regulations on AI companies. Conservative concerns about Big Tech extend beyond Palantir. Bannon has publicly sparred with Elon Musk and questioned Trump‚Äôs embrace of Silicon Valley. Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis has warned about the energy demands of data centers. Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican, has led congressional investigations into the harms chatbots may cause children. But even as skepticism on the right grows, Vance‚Äôs standing in Silicon Valley remains an asset ‚Äî and a source of speculation. Asked recently by Axios‚Äô Mike Allen whom he hoped would replace Trump, Karp did not name Vance but described a figure who closely resembled the ‚ÄúHillbilly Elegy‚Äù author: someone who could keep the border sealed, uphold conservative cultural norms and ‚Äúcredibly fight for workers.‚Äù Allen replied: ‚ÄúThat sounds like the current Vice President.‚Äù
news.author: Steve Contorno

news.title: Trump calls ‚Äòtraitor‚Äô Marjorie Taylor Greene a ‚Äònice person‚Äô as longtime rival Laura Loomer flames ‚Äòparasite‚Äô
news.text:
There was more MAGA rage Saturday following Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene‚Äôs (R-Ga.) stunning announcement that she will resign from Congress ‚Äî with longtime Trump ally Laura Loomer branding her as an ‚Äúevil, parasitic woman.‚Äù

Loomer piled on after President Trump initially slammed Greene in an early morning post labeling her ‚ÄúMarjorie ‚ÄòTraitor‚Äô Brown.‚Äù

‚ÄúPresident Trump is basically calling Marjorie Traitor Greene a stage 5 clinger,‚Äù Loomer posted on X. 

Greene‚Äôs congressional pension becomes vested Jan. 3, two days before her announced resignation date and five years after she took office, Loomer pointed out. 

She also slammed Greene as an ‚Äúevil, parasitic woman who smeared me and lied about me for years,‚Äù adding, ‚ÄúI wish her the worst.‚Äù

Lefty ‚ÄúSquad‚Äù member Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez wasted no time in also piling on Greene over the pension issue.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs carefully timing her departure just 1-2 days after her pension kicks in,‚Äù the Bronx rep posted on Instagram.

After initially slamming Greene in an early Saturday Truth Social post which read in part, ‚ÄúMarjorie went BAD,‚Äù the president appeared to soften his stance.

Asked by a reporter at the White House later in the day if he would forgive Greene, Trump replied: ‚ÄúForgive for what? I just disagreed with her philosophy.‚Äù

Then he talked up her political career in a brief interview with NBC.

 ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going to be easy for her‚Äù to bring back her career in politics, he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd love to see that.‚Äù

Trump also advised that ‚Äúshe‚Äôs got to take a little rest.‚Äù

Loomer and Greene clashed last year after Loomer, a conspiracy theorist who traveled with Trump during the campaign, attacked then-VP Kamala Harris. 

She said if Harris won ‚Äúthe White House will smell like curry & White House speeches will be facilitated via a call center.‚Äù Greene, who has called Loomer a ‚Äúliar,‚Äù called the comment ‚Äúextremely racist.‚Äù

Greene‚Äôs departure makes House Speaker Mike Johnson‚Äôs already narrow six-vote majority even tighter.

Without Greene, there will be a lively primary in a district outside of Atlanta speckled with mid-sized cities including Rome, Georgia, a state operative said.

Georgia holds its regular primary election in May. Gov. Brian Kemp (R-Ga.) must decide whether to hold an earlier special election, possibly in March, to fill Greene‚Äôs seat.

For years, Greene had been one of Trump‚Äôs most vocal defenders. But in recent weeks, she broke with the president on the Jeffrey Epstein files, the government shutdown and rising prices.

Political operatives have speculated Greene could run for the governorship, the Senate ‚Äî where Jon Ossoff (D-Ga.) is seeking reelection ‚Äî or even the White House, or continue her recent run of headline-making TV appearances.

‚ÄúWhen the common American people finally realize and understand that the political industrial complex of both parties is ripping this country apart, that not one elected leader like me is able to stop Washington‚Äôs machine from gradually destroying our country,‚Äù she said in her resignation video, ‚Äúand instead the reality is that they, common Americans, the people, possess the real power over Washington, then I‚Äôll be here by their side to rebuild it.‚Äù
news.summary: Marjorie Taylor Greene‚Äôs (R-Ga.) stunning announcement Friday that she will resign from Congress sets up a political battle in her deep red district, and leaves her free to plot a new independent course outside or alongside MAGA.
news.author: Geoff Earle

news.title: Five Reasons Donald Trump Fell For Zohran Mamdani
news.text:
Sure, we know Mamdani is charming, but so is Barack Obama, another leader Trump has spent friendly-seeming time with, even as he falsely accuses Obama of treason. So it's got to be more than Mamdani's charisma. Here, we offer up five theories to explain what Vanity Fair's Aidan McLaughlin described as a ‚Äúlovefest.‚Äù
Trump is powerless in the presence of a beard
Name the powerful bearded politician who made these comments about Donald Trump:

‚ÄúTrump is a cynical asshole ‚Ä¶ he‚Äôs America‚Äôs Hitler.‚Äù
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think he actually cares about folks.‚Äù
‚ÄùHe‚Äôs noxious and is leading the white working class to a very dark place."

Ted Cruz? No, I said ‚Äúpowerful.‚Äù It's Vice-Presdent J.D. Vance! Before Friday, the only things Vance and Mamdani had in common were a track record of Trump opposition and a beard. After Friday, they could add Trump's glowing praise to the list of commonalities. Fox News host Brian Kilmeade might be on a similar track as I am, saying ‚ÄúI think J.D. Vance is jealous" as he discussed Friday's event.
Trump watched Heat Thursday night
Everyone agrees that the coffee shop meeting between Al Pacino and Robert De Niro's characters is the most indelible scene in Michael Mann's classic 1995 film Heat. Nemeses in the same room, the grudging respect between hero and villain, the growing understanding that the opposites are far more alike than they realized‚Ä¶it's one of the world's most compelling narratives, from Batman and the Joker to the horseshoe theory.
Mamdani looked in Trump's left eye
According to the New York Post, which appears to be where most of Middle America gets their Zohran Mamdani news, MIT prof Tara Swart says that mothers and their babies bond using right eye to left eye contact. ‚ÄúMost people are right-handed so they‚Äôll be holding their baby in their left arm, so they can use their dominant hand to do stuff," she says. ‚ÄúThat means when you gaze at your baby, your right eye is looking at their left and then that interaction from the optic nerve is going around the brain.‚Äù According to Swart, that eye contact creates an ‚Äúemotional resonance loop that‚Äôs part of how the mother and baby bond.‚Äù So, if we assume that Trump was able to keep his eyes open during the private meeting he had with Mamdani prior to the press event, Mamdani might have been able to provide the president with enough maternal good vibes to briefly counteract Trump's awful-sounding upbringing by Fred Trump.
Some Mamdani-loving billionaire got on the horn
Long branded a horrific hellhole by Fox News, San Francisco has been bracing for Trump to deploy the National Guard to the famously liberal town since he started rolling troops into Democrat-led cities earlier this year. In October, the incursion seemed inevitable‚Äîthat is, until a couple oligarchs, including billionaire Salesforce founder Marc Benioff and billionaire Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang, called Trump and told him to stand down. Trump complied.
‚ÄúOne of the things that President Trump is really good at is he‚Äôs a really good listener,‚Äù Huang told the SF Chronicle about the call. ‚ÄúIf you appeal to him, logically, pragmatically, with common sense, he will listen.‚Äù Benioff's Mamdami-aligned creds have recently taken a beating, but it wasn‚Äôt that long ago that he backed a hefty tax on large corporations to generate funds to fight homelessness. And Benioff was a White House guest on Tuesday, at the president's dinner to fete Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. An ideal time, perhaps, to take the president aside and suggest a warm and friendly approach.
Donald Trump has been engaging in the greatest long con of all time
Remember when Donald Trump was on Sex and the City? When he donated to Kamala Harris's campaign when she ran for California Attorney General? When he told CNN ‚ÄúI probably identify more as a Democrat‚Ä¶And it just seems that the economy does better under the Democrats than the Republicans‚Äù? Some pundits describe his remarkable change in position as a set of craven flip-flops, a symptom of someone who lacks a belief in anything but power, or a sign of ‚Äúaccelerating cognitive decline.‚Äù
But Occam's Razor is overrated! What if, as Mamdani's election rival Curtis Sliwa claimed last night, ‚Äúwe all got played‚Äù? Is Trump about to reveal himself as a deep cover mole for The Resistance? It's 2025, don't rule it out.
news.summary: Anyone expecting fireworks when New York City's mayor-elect met with the president was disappointed Friday‚Äîunless they were hoping for an explosion of love.
news.author: Eve Batey

news.title: Trump ends deportation protection for Somalis in Minnesota
news.text:
Nov. 22 (UPI) -- President Donald Trump said he is "immediately" ending deportation protections for more than 400 Somali immigrants living in Minnesota.

Trumo made the announcement on Truth Social on Friday night.

The East African nation has had protection since 1991, and it was renewed on Sept. 18, 2024, through March 17, 2026, when Joe Biden was president.

"I am, as President of the United States, hereby terminating, effective immediately, the Temporary Protected Status (TPS Program) for Somalis in Minnesota," he wrote. "Somali gangs are terrorizing the people of that great State, and BILLIONS of Dollars are missing. Send them back to where they came from. It's OVER!"

He did not offer evidence related to the allegations of terrorist gangs in the state.

In addition, he blamed Democratic Gov. Walz of overseeing a state that had become a "hub of fraudulent money laundering activity" -- also without proof.

"It's not surprising that the President has chosen to broadly target an entire community. This is what he does to change the subject," Walz, who was Kamala Harris' vice presidential candidate in the 2024 election against Trump, said less than two hours later in a post on X.

TPS was created in 1979 to allow migrants who escaped "civil unrest, violence or natural disasters" from being deported from the United Stats.

Somalia, which for decades has experienced civil war and instability, is among 17 migrants' countries with protection. Somalia's population is 20 million.

There are 705 Somali immigrants approved for the status as of March 31 with 430 in Minnesota, according to a Congressional Research Service report.

The Cedar-Riverside neighborhood east of downtown Minneapolis is nicknamed "Little Mogadishu" because of its large Somali population.

Rep. Ilhan Omar, a Democrat representing Minneapolis and born in Somalia, blasted the decision.

"Good luck celebrating a policy change that really doesn't have much impact on the Somalis you love to hate. We are here to stay," Omar wrote on X, noting that most Somalian immigrants are U.S. citizens.

Trump in the past has been at odds with Omar.

"I look at somebody that comes from Somalia, where they don't have anything - they don't have police, they don't have military, they don't have anything," Trump said in a Nov. 11 interview with Laura Ingraham on Fox News. "All they have is crime -- and she comes in and tells us how to run our country."

Since 1979, more than 26,000 Somali refugees moved to Minnesota, according to the state Department of Health.

Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison, a Democrat, said his office is "monitoring the situation and exploring all of our options.

"Somali folks came to Minnesota fleeing conflict, instability and famine, and they have become an integral part of our state, our culture and our community," Ellison wrote on Facebook. "Donald Trump cannot terminate TPS for just one state or on a bigoted whim."

"I am confident that Minnesotans know better than to fall for Donald Trump's scare tactics and scapegoating," he added.

Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey also spoke out with a Facebook post that he is "standing with our Somali community today. Minneapolis has your back -- always."

Republican House Speaker Lisa Demuthg, who is running for governor against Walz, applauded the decision.

"The unfortunate reality is that far too many individuals who were welcomed into this country have abused the trust and support that was extended to them, and Minnesota taxpayers have suffered billions of dollars in consequences as a result," Demuth said in a statement to the Minnesota Star Tribune.

Minnesota Republican U.S. Rep. Tom Emmer adding a post posted on X that "accountability is coming."

Emmers post linked to a report from right-wing Breitbart about a letter he wrote to Daniel Rosen, U.S. attorney for the District of Minnesota, urging him to "open an investigation into reports that Minnesota taxpayer dollars are ending up in the hands of the al-Shabab terrorist network in Somalia."

The move was criticized by Jaylani Hussein, president of the Minnesota chapter of the Council on American-Islamic Relations.

"This is not just a bureaucratic change; it is a political attack on the Somali and Muslim community driven by Islamophobic and hateful rhetoric," Hussein told CBS News. "We strongly urge President Trump to reverse this misguided decision."

He added that the protection provided "a legal lifeline for families who have built their lives here for decades."

Trump has also ended TPS protections for Afghan, Venezuelan, Syrian and South Sudanese nationals. Those actions from each have been challenged in courts.
news.summary: President Donald Trump said he is "immediately" ending deportation protections for more than 400 Somali immigrants living in Minnesota.
news.author: Allen Cone

news.title: Bill Maher Criticizes Michelle Obama, Asserts Confidence in America‚Äôs Readiness for Female President
news.text:
Bill Maher recently critiqued Michelle Obama, suggesting she carries a ‚Äúbad attitude‚Äù following her remarks about the readiness of American voters to elect a woman president. Maher expressed his surprise at her comments on a recent episode of ‚ÄúReal Time with Bill Maher.‚Äù

Michelle Obama, during a November 5 event on her book tour, implied that sexism remains a hurdle in electing a female president. Her comments came just a day after Democratic women Mikie Sherrill and Abigail Spanberger achieved significant victories in gubernatorial races in New Jersey and Virginia, respectively.

Reflecting on Kamala Harris‚Äôs past electoral defeat to Donald Trump, Obama stated, ‚ÄúAs we saw in this past election, sadly, we ain‚Äôt ready.‚Äù She further explained her reluctance to run for office, saying, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why I‚Äôm like, don‚Äôt even look at me about running, because you all are lying. You‚Äôre not ready for a woman.‚Äù

Obama‚Äôs comments underscore her belief that societal growth is needed, as she remarked, ‚ÄúWe got a lot of growing up to do, and there are still, sadly, a lot of men who do not feel like they can be led by a woman, and we saw it.‚Äù

‚ÄòAs we saw in this past election, sadly, we ain‚Äôt ready,‚Äô she said, talking about Kamala Harris‚Äô loss to Trump. ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs why I‚Äôm like, don‚Äôt even look at me about running, because you all are lying. You‚Äôre not ready for a woman.‚Äô 

‚ÄòWe got a lot of growing up to do, and there are still, sadly, a lot of men who do not feel like they can be led by a woman, and we saw it.‚Äô

Maher didn‚Äôt buy this, instead arguing it came down to the unique weaknesses of the two women who have gotten the Democratic nomination thus far: Hillary Clinton in 2016 and Harris in 2024.

‚ÄòTo me, this is logical fallacy 101. Just because we weren‚Äôt ready or didn‚Äôt like the candidates, Hillary and Kamala, doesn‚Äôt mean we‚Äôre not ready for a woman,‚Äô he said.

‚ÄòI think it‚Äôs a bad attitude. I do,‚Äô he went on to say. ‚ÄòWe said we weren‚Äôt ready for a black president, and someone, I can‚Äôt remember who, maybe she remembers.‚Äô

Maher concluded by saying, ‚ÄòMaybe it just has to be the right one.‚Äô

Stephen A. Smith, the sports commentator who has been increasingly wading into politics, has also condemned Michelle‚Äôs pessimism about female presidential contenders.

On his SiriusXM radio show this week, he pointed out that Clinton had nearly 3 million more votes than Donald Trump in the 2016.

Of course, she lost the electoral college because Trump had just enough votes in crucial battleground states such as Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania to come out on top.

‚ÄòWhat do you mean we weren‚Äôt ready? What do you mean we weren‚Äôt ready?‚Äô he said. 

‚ÄòWeren‚Äôt there white women who voted for Donald Trump? Not just white men. Didn‚Äôt the blacks show up for Hillary Rodham Clinton? Didn‚Äôt Hispanics show up for Hillary Rodham Clinton?‚Äô

After blaming Clinton for campaigning poorly in swing states that year, Smith then turned to Harris‚Äô run in 2024, which he said couldn‚Äôt have been decided by sexism.

He asked: ‚ÄòHow about 2024 when Kamala Harris was running as the Democratic nominee for the presidency of the United States of America? Yes, she did only have 107 days to do it. But whose fault was that?‚Äô 

Smith then blamed Democrats for holding on ‚Äòto Joe Biden for dear life until July of that summer when there was evidence that showed months earlier that he wasn‚Äôt ready anymore.‚Äô 

He slammed Harris for being ‚Äòhesitant to do interviews, hesitant to answer questions and you were hesitant to separate yourself from the Biden administration in terms of some of the decisions that they made.‚Äô

Smith added that he believed Michelle could be the first woman president, though she has expressed a distaste for politics.

‚ÄòYou are not just beloved, you are revered, you are sensational in so many ways. I‚Äôve been on the record on this show and many others stating: ‚ÄúHad you run for president, you would have beat Trump.‚Äù I still believe that.‚Äô
news.summary:
Internewscast Journal

Internewscast


Bill Maher recently critiqued Michelle Obama, suggesting she carries a “bad attitude”…

news.title: Bill Maher Calls Michelle Obama‚Äôs Claim That America Isn‚Äôt Ready for a Woman President ‚ÄúBullsh*t‚Äù
news.text:
Bill Maher and former DNC chair Donna Brazile weren‚Äôt having it on Friday night, taking aim at Michelle Obama‚Äôs recent suggestion that Americans still aren‚Äôt ready to elect a woman as president. The pair unpacked the former first lady‚Äôs remarks during the season finale of Real Time, calling her assessment ‚Äî as Maher put it ‚Äî ‚Äúbulls*t.‚Äù

Maher zeroed in on Obama‚Äôs comments from her book tour stop at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last week, where she opened up about why she has no plans to step into the political arena in 2028, despite persistent speculation.

‚ÄúShe was in the news this week, Michelle Obama. She has a book out. A coffee table book,‚Äù Maher said. ‚ÄúHer statement, I was rather shocked by it.

‚ÄúTo me, this is logical fallacy 101. Just because we weren‚Äôt ready or didn‚Äôt like the candidates, Hillary and Kamala, doesn‚Äôt mean we are not ready for a woman.‚Äù

Obama had told moderator Tracee Ellis Ross that her decision not to run stems from what she sees as a deeper issue in American politics. ‚ÄúAs we saw in the past election, sadly, we ain‚Äôt ready,‚Äù she said during the November 5 event. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why I‚Äôm like, don‚Äôt even look at me about running, because you all are lying. You‚Äôre not ready for a woman. You are not. So don‚Äôt waste my time.‚Äù

She doubled down, saying, ‚ÄúWe got a lot of growing up to do and there‚Äôs still, sadly, a lot of men who do not feel like they can be led by a woman, and we saw it.‚Äù

Maher pushed back by invoking her husband‚Äôs historic 2008 victory. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs a bad attitude. We said we weren‚Äôt ready for a black president and someone, I can‚Äôt remember who maybe she remembers, said maybe it just has to be the right one,‚Äù he joked.

Brazile backed Maher up with a numbers-based rebuttal. ‚ÄúWe are ready,‚Äù she said, pointing to the popular vote totals from Hillary Clinton‚Äôs 2016 loss to Donald Trump and Kamala Harris‚Äôs 2024 defeat. Clinton won 65.8 million votes to Trump‚Äôs 62.9 million, while Harris pulled in 75 million in her own losing bid.

‚ÄúMaybe we should stop talking about it and just do it,‚Äù Brazile added, later emphasizing, ‚ÄúWe are ready. Eighty percent of American people say, ‚Äòthey are ready.‚Äô So the idea that America isn‚Äôt ready is bullsh*t. They might not be ready for this one or that one.‚Äù

You can watch a different clip of the panel, which also featured rapper and activist Killer Mike, in Maher‚Äôs ‚ÄúOvertime‚Äù segment from last night‚Äôs episode above.

Maher also stirred things up earlier in the week on his Club Random podcast, where he floated Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY) as a potential White House contender ‚Äî with one caveat.

‚ÄúIf she had some deprogramming, she could be such a fantastic candidate,‚Äù he said of AOC. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs never going to resonate with people outside of the bubble she lives in, in the very, very far left.‚Äù
news.summary: The HBO host pushed back on the former first lady‚Äôs take: ‚ÄúLogical fallacy 101.‚Äù
news.author: Michael Haskoor,mliss1578

news.title: Bill Maher slams Michelle Obama's 'bad attitude' over claim Americans are too sexist to elect female president
news.text:
Bill Maher said Michelle Obama is suffering from a 'bad attitude' after she claimed earlier this month that Americans are still not ready to elect a woman to the presidency.

'Her statement, I was rather shocked by it,' Maher during Friday's episode of Real Time With Bill Maher.

Michelle implied that many male voters are sexist and don't want a woman in the White House during a November 5 stop on her book tour. 

This came a day after two Democratic women, Mikie Sherrill and Abigail Spanberger, cruised to victory in their respective New Jersey and Virginia gubernatorial races.

'As we saw in this past election, sadly, we ain't ready,' she said, talking about Kamala Harris' loss to Trump. 'That's why I'm like, don't even look at me about running, because you all are lying. You're not ready for a woman.' 

'We got a lot of growing up to do, and there are still, sadly, a lot of men who do not feel like they can be led by a woman, and we saw it.'

Maher didn't buy this, instead arguing it came down to the unique weaknesses of the two women who have gotten the Democratic nomination thus far: Hillary Clinton in 2016 and Harris in 2024.

'To me, this is logical fallacy 101. Just because we weren‚Äôt ready or didn‚Äôt like the candidates, Hillary and Kamala, doesn‚Äôt mean we‚Äôre not ready for a woman,' he said.

'I think it‚Äôs a bad attitude. I do,' he went on to say. 'We said we weren‚Äôt ready for a black president, and someone, I can‚Äôt remember who, maybe she remembers.'

Maher concluded by saying, 'Maybe it just has to be the right one.'

Stephen A. Smith, the sports commentator who has been increasingly wading into politics, has also condemned Michelle's pessimism about female presidential contenders.

On his SiriusXM radio show this week, he pointed out that Clinton had nearly 3 million more votes than Donald Trump in the 2016.

Of course, she lost the electoral college because Trump had just enough votes in crucial battleground states such as Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania to come out on top.

'What do you mean we weren't ready? What do you mean we weren't ready?' he said. 

'Weren't there white women who voted for Donald Trump? Not just white men. Didn't the blacks show up for Hillary Rodham Clinton? Didn't Hispanics show up for Hillary Rodham Clinton?'

After blaming Clinton for campaigning poorly in swing states that year, Smith then turned to Harris' run in 2024, which he said couldn't have been decided by sexism.

He asked: 'How about 2024 when Kamala Harris was running as the Democratic nominee for the presidency of the United States of America? Yes, she did only have 107 days to do it. But whose fault was that?' 

Smith then blamed Democrats for holding on 'to Joe Biden for dear life until July of that summer when there was evidence that showed months earlier that he wasn't ready anymore.' 

He slammed Harris for being 'hesitant to do interviews, hesitant to answer questions and you were hesitant to separate yourself from the Biden administration in terms of some of the decisions that they made.'

Smith added that he believed Michelle could be the first woman president, though she has expressed a distaste for politics.

'You are not just beloved, you are revered, you are sensational in so many ways. I've been on the record on this show and many others stating: "Had you run for president, you would have beat Trump." I still believe that.
news.summary: The comedian disagreed with the former first lady, saying America could be ready for a woman in the White House - it just has to be the right one.
news.author: Editor,James Cirrone

news.title: Trump Administration Revokes Deportation Protections: Impact on Somali Community in Minnesota
news.text:
Donald Trump has declared his intention to terminate deportation protections for Somali immigrants residing in Minnesota.

In a fiery post on Truth Social, the former president alleged that the state is being overwhelmed by ‚ÄòSomali gangs causing chaos‚Äô.

Trump also criticized Governor Mike Waltz, who is the running mate of Kamala Harris in the upcoming 2024 election, accusing him of allowing Minnesota to become ‚Äòa center for fraudulent money laundering schemes‚Äô.

He claimed, ‚ÄòBILLIONS of Dollars are missing,‚Äô during his online outburst.

Wrapping up his message, Trump stated, ‚ÄòSend them back to where they came from. It‚Äôs OVER! President DJT.‚Äô

Trump has announced plans to revoke the Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for Somali nationals in Minnesota. This federal program, established in the 1990s, permits individuals from conflict-ridden or dangerous regions to reside and work legally in the United States.

Somalia has been locked in a devastating civil war since 1991, and the turmoil has triggered several bouts of intense fighting among Somali militias and famine. 

According to Congress.gov data, there are 705 Somali immigrants in the entire nation approved for TPS, and Somali‚Äôs TPS designation does not expire until March 17, 2026. 

Minnesota has the largest Somali population in the United States at an estimated 86,000 people, and the influx of migrants from the African nation has dramatically influenced the state‚Äôs politics ‚Äì including re-elected Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey speaking in Somali during his victory speech this month. 

Trump did not offer details of the alleged fraud in Minnesota, but it comes after the City Journal reported that millions of dollars may have been stolen from Minnesota welfare schemes and funneled to Somalia-based terror group al-Shabab. 

Trump has also moved to remove TPS protections for a number of other nations since he retook the White House this year, including Venezuela, Afghanistan, Syria, and South Sudan. 

Trump‚Äôs post announcing that he would end TPS for Somali migrants in Minnesota divided opinions, as Democrats raged against the president‚Äôs move. 

Waltz took to X to condemn the action, writing: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs not surprising that the President has chosen to broadly target an entire community. 

‚ÄòThis is what he does to change the subject.‚Äô 

Minnesota Rep. Ilhan Omar, who has frequently clashed with Trump and was told by the president to ‚Äògo back‚Äô to Somalia just weeks ago, also slammed the removal of TPS protections. 

In response to a post citing Trump‚Äôs announcement that told her to ‚Äògo back where you came from‚Äô, Omar wrote: ‚ÄòI am a citizen and so are majority of Somalis in America. 

‚ÄòGood luck celebrating a policy change that really doesn‚Äôt have much impact on the Somalis you love to hate. We are here to stay.‚Äô 

But while Democrats fumed over Trump‚Äôs announcement, Republican Minnesota House Speaker Lisa Demuth said she was ‚Äòglad‚Äô to see the White House look into Minnesota‚Äôs ‚Äòfraud problem.‚Äô 

‚ÄòThe unfortunate reality is that far too many individuals who were welcomed into this country have abused the trust and support that was extended to them, and Minnesota taxpayers have suffered billions of dollars in consequences as a result,‚Äô she told CBS News. 

Jaylani Hussein, president of the Minnesota chapter of the Council on American-Islamic Relations, added to CBS that Trump‚Äôs announcement was ‚Äòmisguided.‚Äô 

‚ÄòThis is not just a bureaucratic change; it is a political attack on the Somali and Muslim community driven by Islamophobic and hateful rhetoric,‚Äô he said. 

‚Äò(We are) deeply disappointed that the administration has chosen to end the Somali TPS program in Minnesota, a legal lifeline for families who have built their lives here for decades. 

‚ÄòWe strongly urge President Trump to reverse this misguided decision.‚Äô

news.title: 'The View' Co-Host Joy Behar Thinks Conservative Woman Could Win Presidency 'Faster than a Liberal'
news.text:
ABC‚Äôs The View co-host Joy Behar said this week that she believes ‚Äúa conservative woman would win‚Äù the U.S. presidency ‚Äúfaster than a liberal‚Äù candidate.

During the show‚Äôs podcast, The View producer Brian Teta asked Behar and co-host Sunny Hostin if ‚Äúthe country is getting more comfortable with women leaders,‚Äù to which Hostin replied, ‚ÄúMaybe a woman, but not a black woman, ever. Not in my lifetime.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs possible that somebody like a Liz Cheney could win if she wasn‚Äôt in the doghouse with her own Party right now,‚Äù Behar said. ‚ÄúShe could be somebody who could run. I think maybe a conservative woman would win faster than a liberal.‚Äù

Teta concurred, replying, ‚ÄúA lot of people think that. A lot of people think a conservative woman might win first.‚Äù

‚ÄúA white conservative woman, yes,‚Äù Hostin clarified, still fixating on race, before suggesting that perhaps a female president may not be in the cards anytime soon. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of misogyny in this country.‚Äù

Teta then chimed in, saying, ‚ÄúIt was hard to imagine after Obama was elected the first time that we‚Äôd ever be back where we are now.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think Trump‚Äôs election is a reaction to having a black president,‚Äù Hostin asserted.

On Monday‚Äôs episode of The View, the women discussed former First Lady Michelle Obama‚Äôs recent remarks in which she argued that the United States is ‚Äúnot ready for a woman‚Äù to be president.

During the conversation, Behar pointed out that other countries ‚Äî such as Italy, Iceland, and Mexico ‚Äî have already elected female leaders, before claiming that the United States is ‚Äúthe only country‚Äù that hasn‚Äôt.

‚ÄúI respectfully disagree with the First Lady,‚Äù The View co-host Alyssa Farah Griffin said of Michelle Obama‚Äôs comments.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that we‚Äôre not ready,‚Äù Griffin continued. ‚ÄúI think when you look at the two candidates that were Democratic nominees, Hillary Clinton and Kamala Harris, there‚Äôs always sexism that plays in, [but] they were flawed candidates.‚Äù

Hostin then chimed in to opine (and again focused on race) that the United States ‚Äî which elected its first black president in 2008 ‚Äî is ‚Äúbased on racism and slavery,‚Äù thus too racist and misogynistic to ever elect a black woman as president.

‚ÄúBecause of my lived experience as an Afro Latina, I‚Äôm able to look at this world with a different prism, and I‚Äôm able to tell this country and tell this audience and tell my fellow co-hosts some uncomfortable truths,‚Äù Hostin declared.

‚ÄúThis is a country based on racism and slavery, and founded in it, there is systemic racism and misogyny,‚Äù she added.

Alana Mastrangelo is a reporter for Breitbart News. You can follow her on Facebook and X at @ARmastrangelo, and on Instagram.
news.summary:
ABC's "The View" co-host Joy Behar said this week that she believes "a conservative woman would win" the U.S. presidency "faster than a liberal" candidate.

news.title: James Carville warns Dems to address affordability crisis or ‚Äòthis thing could break‚Äô
news.text:
Veteran Democratic strategist James Carville warned Thursday that any American president going forward must confront the affordability crisis facing young people.

‚ÄúThe thing that‚Äôs coming in this country, and we‚Äôre not ready for it, and that is the accumulation of generational wealth by our generation,‚Äù Carville said on his ‚ÄúPolitics War Room‚Äù podcast.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just these stories that are coming out, and the young people have just ‚Ä¶ they‚Äôre just having it terribly. They can‚Äôt buy houses. They can‚Äôt educate anybody. There was the CEO of Ford saying there‚Äôs 5,000 auto mechanic jobs that they have that they can‚Äôt fill.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think that this country made two bad bets,‚Äù Carville added, ‚ÄúAnd they both seemed like good bets at the time. One is we decided we‚Äôre going to be a nation of homeowners. And, two, that we were going to be a nation of people that went to college. Both of those strategies are, in effect, blowing up in our faces.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe next president is going to have to rethink this and is going to have to embrace some economic populism because I‚Äôm going to tell you, this thing could break. And if somebody doesn‚Äôt get ahead of it, it‚Äôs going to get ahead of everybody else,‚Äù Carville said. 

‚ÄúAnd people are starting to get really pissed. They‚Äôre starting to figure out what‚Äôs happened to their lives.‚Äù

Carville is one of several commentators who have sounded the alarm on the issue, as many Democrats have been debating how to appeal to young male voters struggling to enter the middle class in a changing, globalized economy.

In March 2024, months before President Donald Trump defeated former Vice President Kamala Harris in the presidential election, Carville warned Democrats to abandon woke politics, arguing the party was dominated by ‚Äútoo many preachy females,‚Äù both of which, he said, were alienating male voters. 

On Thursday, Carville said many younger Americans are ‚Äústarting to figure out why they don‚Äôt have a lot of hope to get a good job or to be able to buy a house. Because, people, once we all bought houses, we put zoning restrictions and God knows what else just to drive the price of the asset up, which our price of our asset goes up, the price of what a young person has to pay goes up too.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got to really rethink this whole idea of four-year college and homeownership.‚Äù
news.summary: Democratic strategist James Carville issued a warning on his "Politics War Room" podcast that any U.S. president going forward has to address the affordability crisis young people are facing.
news.author: Fox News

news.title: Trump tears up deportation protection for Somalis in Minnesota in brutal shock move that could see them sent back to war-torn homeland
news.text:
Donald Trump says he is ending deportation protections for Somali immigrants in Minnesota. 

The president claimed in a blistering Truth Social post that the Blue state is being overrun by 'Somali gangs terrorizing people'.

Trump also called out Governor Mike Waltz, the running mate of his 2024 opponent Kamala Harris, for allowing his state to become 'a hub of fraudulent money laundering activity.' 

'BILLIONS of Dollars are missing,' Trump wrote in his tirade. 

'Send them back to where they came from. It‚Äôs OVER! President DJT.' 

He announced he will be ending the Temporary Protected Status (TPS Program) for Somalis in Minnesota, a federal initiative introduced in the 1990s that allows migrants from war-torn or unsafe countries to live and work legally in the US. 

Somalia has been locked in a devastating civil war since 1991, and the turmoil has triggered several bouts of intense fighting among Somali militias and famine. 

According to Congress.gov data, there are 705 Somali immigrants in the entire nation approved for TPS, and Somali's TPS designation does not expire until March 17, 2026. 

Minnesota has the largest Somali population in the United States at an estimated 86,000 people, and the influx of migrants from the African nation has dramatically influenced the state's politics - including re-elected Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey speaking in Somali during his victory speech this month. 

Trump did not offer details of the alleged fraud in Minnesota, but it comes after the City Journal reported that millions of dollars may have been stolen from Minnesota welfare schemes and funneled to Somalia-based terror group al-Shabab. 

Trump has also moved to remove TPS protections for a number of other nations since he retook the White House this year, including Venezuela, Afghanistan, Syria, and South Sudan. 

Trump's post announcing that he would end TPS for Somali migrants in Minnesota divided opinions, as Democrats raged against the president's move. 

Waltz took to X to condemn the action, writing: 'It‚Äôs not surprising that the President has chosen to broadly target an entire community. 

'This is what he does to change the subject.' 

Minnesota Rep. Ilhan Omar, who has frequently clashed with Trump and was told by the president to 'go back' to Somalia just weeks ago, also slammed the removal of TPS protections. 

In response to a post citing Trump's announcement that told her to 'go back where you came from', Omar wrote: 'I am a citizen and so are majority of Somalis in America. 

'Good luck celebrating a policy change that really doesn‚Äôt have much impact on the Somalis you love to hate. We are here to stay.' 

But while Democrats fumed over Trump's announcement, Republican Minnesota House Speaker Lisa Demuth said she was 'glad' to see the White House look into Minnesota's 'fraud problem.' 

'The unfortunate reality is that far too many individuals who were welcomed into this country have abused the trust and support that was extended to them, and Minnesota taxpayers have suffered billions of dollars in consequences as a result,' she told CBS News. 

Jaylani Hussein, president of the Minnesota chapter of the Council on American-Islamic Relations, added to CBS that Trump's announcement was 'misguided.' 

'This is not just a bureaucratic change; it is a political attack on the Somali and Muslim community driven by Islamophobic and hateful rhetoric,' he said. 

'(We are) deeply disappointed that the administration has chosen to end the Somali TPS program in Minnesota, a legal lifeline for families who have built their lives here for decades. 

'We strongly urge President Trump to reverse this misguided decision.
news.summary: The president wrote on his Truth Social platform that the Blue state was overran by 'Somali gangs terrorizing people' as he said he was ending the decades-long TPS program in Minnesota.
news.author: Editor,Will Potter

news.title: Billionaire Meets with White House to Discuss Potential CNN Anchor Changes Amid Son‚Äôs Interest in Network Acquisition
news.text:
In a recent development, Larry Ellison, the billionaire father of David Ellison, who owns Paramount, has been rumored to suggest major changes at CNN if his son successfully acquires Warner Bros Discovery, the network‚Äôs parent company. This information comes from a new report.

According to insiders speaking with The Guardian, Larry Ellison discussed the potential removal of prominent CNN hosts Erin Burnett and Brianna Keilar during conversations with White House officials. The sources noted that the anchors were mentioned due to their lack of favor with former President Donald Trump.

The 81-year-old Oracle co-founder is also said to have considered a shift in programming that would integrate the iconic CBS News program, 60 Minutes, into CNN‚Äôs lineup. This consideration follows Paramount‚Äôs recent acquisition by his son, David, a deal that Larry Ellison helped finance.

The report, released on Thursday, has generated buzz within CNN‚Äôs New York City headquarters located at Hudson Yards, as reported by Status.

David Ellison, who is 42, has reportedly made an undisclosed offer for the entire Warner Bros Discovery portfolio, which includes CNN.

David Ellison, 42, has entered an unknown bid for the entire WBD portfolio, including CNN.

Larry and David are the only prospective WBD bidders who want to buy CNN as part of any deal. Others are said to be willing to spin off the ailing cable network into a separate company while focusing on more promising assets like Warner Bros. movie studio and HBO. 

Larry Ellison, a well-known GOP donor, donated to Trump‚Äôs 2024 campaign and does not play a formal role within Paramount.

 He is, however, the company‚Äôs primary shareholder ‚Äì and he fourth-richest man in the world with a net worth of nearly $200billion.

The Daily Mail has reached out to Paramount for comment on the report Friday. Reps from CNN declined to comment. 

Burnett, 49, has been with CNN since 2011 after joining from CNBC. Keilar , 45, joined CNN as a correspondent in 2006, after several years with CBS News. The two have offered critical reporting Trump for years, but are far from the only CNN stars known for targeting the president. 

Burnett ‚Äì currently the host of hour-long primetime program Erin Burnett OutFront ‚Äì last week tore into the conservative for what she saw as inconsistencies in his story about Jeffrey Epstein on November 13.

On Thursday, she hosted Democratic Rep. Chrissy Houlahan to criticize Trump for accusing six Democratic lawmakers of of ‚Äòseditious behavior, punishable by death‚Äô for a video urging members of the military to not follow orders if they are unlawful.

Keilar did the same later in the night on News Central with Congressman Chris Deluzio (D-PA), one of the politicians in the video, calling Trump‚Äôs comments ‚Äòoutrageous.‚Äô

Last year, she tore into the president for his false claims about Haitian immigrants.

The news comes after former New York Times opinion editor Bari Weiss was minted as CBS News‚Äô chief on October 6 after ‚Äòinformally consulting‚Äô the network for weeks, a source told the Daily Mail last month.

David Ellison personally headhunted Weiss after buying Paramount in July.

She is said to be keen to hire a new evening news star, with Fox News host Bret Baier and CNN favorite Anderson Cooper among her rumored top picks. Weiss resigned from Times in 2021 to found the Free Press, which was purchased by Ellison in October for roughly $150 million.

After being named CEO, Ellison pledged to shed any prior political connotations that may be tied to the company after a string of controversies and claims of ‚Äòdeceptive‚Äô editing practices from both Donald Trump and Homeland Security boss Kristi Noem.

Before the merger, Paramount balked at settling a lawsuit with Trump that claimed a 60 Minutes interview with a then-campaigning Kamala Harris was ‚Äòdeceptively edited.‚Äô

The suit was settled for $16million days before the FCC approved the merger. 

Other companies who have entered a bid for Warner Bros. Discovery ‚Äì sans CNN ‚Äì include NBC News parent Comcast and Netflix.
